You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 479]]<|/det|> - Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page. - Write your answer to each question in the space provided. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 497, 482, 512]]<|/det|> - Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid. - Do not write on any bar codes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 526, 325, 542]]<|/det|> - You may use a calculator. - You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[91, 591, 214, 602]]<|/det|> # INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 607, 388, 620]]<|/det|> - The total mark for this paper is 40. - The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
1 A student investigates the behaviour of a spring, and then uses the spring to determine the mass of an object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 121, 410, 138]]<|/det|>
The apparatus is shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[344, 154, 642, 372]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[466, 392, 532, 409]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 423, 625, 440]]<|/det|>
(a) The student suspends a mass \(m=100 \mathrm{~g}\) from the spring. She measures, and records in Table 1.1, the stretched length \(l\) of the spring, as indicated

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 454, 247, 471]]<|/det|>
in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 486, 918, 502]]<|/det|>

1

2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 896, 91]]<|/det|>
(e) Two students measure the mass of another object using the same method and apparatus. One student records the mass as 132.6 g . The other student records the mass as 130 g .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 121, 918, 137]]<|/det|>
State and explain which answer has the more suitable number of significant figures for this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 168, 245, 181]]<|/det|>
statement

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 199, 256, 214]]<|/det|>
explanation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 32, 964, 97]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the effect of insulation on the cooling of water. 2 A student investigates the effect of insulation on the cooling of water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 105, 457, 122]]<|/det|>
He uses the apparatus shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 136, 609, 150]]<|/det|>
Beaker A is covered with material that is a thermal insulator.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 168, 567, 181]]<|/det|>
Beaker B is identical to beaker A but has no insulation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 918, 91]]<|/det|> (b) The student pours \(200 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) of hot water into beaker A and records the temperature \(\theta\) at time \(t=0\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 121, 802, 138]]<|/det|> He records, in Table 2.1, the temperature of the water in the beaker every 30 s . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 152, 555, 167]]<|/det|> The student repeats the procedure for beaker B. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 181, 736, 198]]<|/det|> It is important that the temperatures are recorded at exactly every 30 s . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 213, 747, 230]]<|/det|> Describe a technique which will make it easier for the student to do that. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 336, 540, 352]]<|/det|> <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[270, 365, 727, 597]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 372, 550, 403]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[333, 409, 363, 426]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[350, 435, 365, 448]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[341, 458, 365, 474]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[341, 483, 365, 498]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[341, 508, 365, 524]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[341, 533, 365, 549]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[341, 577, 365, 592]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 611, 918, 628]]<|/det|> (c) Write a conclusion stating whether the insulation affects the rate of cooling of the water. Justify your answer by referring to values from the results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
(d) (i) Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{1}\) during the first half of the experiment for the water in beaker B. Use the readings for beaker B from Table 2.1 and the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[441, 118, 556, 151]]<|/det|>
\[
x_{1}=\frac{\theta_{0}-\theta_{90}}{T},
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 160, 918, 178]]<|/det|>
where \(T=90 \mathrm{~s}\) and \(\theta_{0}\) and \(\theta_{90}\) are the temperatures of the water in beaker B at times \(t=0\) and \(t=90 \mathrm{~s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 206, 330, 221]]<|/det|>
Include the unit.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 269, 588, 286]]<|/det|>
\[
x_{1}=
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[894, 269, 919, 285]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 298, 918, 315]]<|/det|>
(ii) Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{2}\) during the second half of the experiment for the water in beaker B. Use the readings for beaker B from Table 2.1 and the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[434, 341, 565, 375]]<|/det|>
\[
x_{2}=\frac{\theta_{90}-\theta_{180}}{T},
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[194, 384, 921, 403]]<|/det|>
where \(T=90 \mathrm{~s}\) and \(\theta_{90}\) and \(\theta_{180}\) are the temperatures of the water in beaker B at \(t=90 \mathrm{~s}\) and \(t=180 \mathrm{~s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 429, 330, 446]]<|/det|>
Include the unit.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 493, 588, 511]]<|/det|>
\[
x_{2}=
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[894, 493, 919, 509]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 523, 918, 540]]<|/det|>
(e) A student suggests that, for this type of experiment, the temperature of the water in each beaker at time \(t=0\) must be the same for the comparison to be fair.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 567, 785, 587]]<|/det|>
Use your answers from (d)(i) and (d)(ii) to explain whether this is necessary.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
(f) (i) A student wants to eliminate, from the comparison, any thermal energy lost from the surface of the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 121, 640, 138]]<|/det|>
Suggest a change to the equipment which will do that.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 213, 921, 230]]<|/det|>
(ii) Suggest what effect this change will have on the cooling rates of the water in beaker A and beaker B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 667, 91]]<|/det|>
3 A student investigates the refraction of light by a transparent block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 105, 598, 122]]<|/det|>
The student's ray-trace sheet is shown full-size in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 135, 877, 772]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[466, 790, 532, 808]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 821, 918, 838]]<|/det|>
(a) The student places a transparent block ABCD near the centre of the ray-trace sheet as indicated in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 868, 918, 885]]<|/det|>
(i) Draw a normal to point \(\mathbf{N}\), extending above \(\mathbf{A B}\). Label the upper end of the normal with the letter L .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 885, 91]]<|/det|>
(e) Describe two techniques to use in this type of experiment to ensure results are accurate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 102, 172, 120]]<|/det|>
1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 165, 174, 183]]<|/det|>
2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 240, 918, 260]]<|/det|>
(f) Suggest one reason why different students, all doing this experiment carefully, may not obtain identical results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 503, 91]]<|/det|>
4 A student investigates the resistance of a wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 105, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment which enables him to investigate how the length of a wire affects the resistance of the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 142, 551, 173]]<|/det|>
Resistance \(R\) is calculated from the equation: \(R=\frac{V}{I}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 181, 834, 199]]<|/det|>
where \(V\) is the potential difference (p.d.) across the wire and \(I\) is the current in the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 213, 399, 230]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 244, 319, 259]]<|/det|>
- a selection of wires - a variable power supply

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 275, 261, 290]]<|/det|>
- an ammeter - a voltmeter.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 320, 225, 339]]<|/det|>
In your plan:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 351, 457, 368]]<|/det|>
- list any additional apparatus needed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 382, 918, 399]]<|/det|>
- complete Fig. 4.1 to show a voltmeter connected to measure the potential difference across the wire

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 429, 918, 446]]<|/det|>
- explain briefly how to do the experiment, including the measurements to take so that the resistance can be determined

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 474, 487, 493]]<|/det|>
- state the key variables to keep constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 505, 918, 524]]<|/det|>
- draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 552, 606, 569]]<|/det|>
- explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion.
